awd_titl_txt: Novel Radio-Frequency (RF)-Modulated Near Infrared (NIR) Electro-Optic Phased Array Imaging Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to develop and investigate a new low-cost, broadband, RF-modulated near-infrared imaging integrated system for detecting breast cancer. The approach is to design a novel electro-optic two-element phased-array system with high spatial resolution to obtain accurate information about the breast tissue's optical scattering and absorption properties. 

Intellectual Merit:  The new imaging system approach will significantly expand the capabilities of non-invasive optical tomography methods. A key innovation of this research is the use of two sources at the transmit side, each comprising an array of multi-wavelength laser diodes in the near-infrared spectral range, to enhance the sensitivity to highly absorptive tissue content (e.g., hemoglobin) and minimize false detection. As a result, the new system is expected to enhance the reliability and accuracy of tomographic reconstruction, significantly improve the spatial resolution of the tissue's optical properties, introduce depth-sectioning capability useful for 3-D imaging, and accurately extract the optical content of the high absorption tissue structures. Significant reduction in power consumption and form factor will make the imaging system suitable for portable use. 

Broader Impacts:  The technological breakthroughs of this research are expected to help provide the medical community with new ways to detect/diagnose breast cancer at a very early stage of development. Reductions in form factor, power, and cost will make imaging systems more widely available to hospitals and individuals across the world. The research project will engage graduate and undergraduate students in a multidisciplinary environment, support outreach activities to students from underrepresented groups and foster industrial and multidisciplinary collaborations.

por.por_cntn:
1. During the first year, the NSF-funded students in the NCIC Labs Published 3 peer-reviewed conference and journal papers. 

2. Presented two conference papers in 2011 RFIC Symposium. One of our RFIC papers entitlled: 'A Fully Integrated 96GHz 2?2 Focal-Plane Array with On-Chip Antenna' was nominated for the Best Paper Award. 

3. Gave several invited talks on the topic of imaging in various organizations including: (a) Hughes Research Labs (HRL), and (2) Boeing. Results of the research funded by this NSF Award were presented to the circuit researchers in those institutions. All of these presentations were highly praised. 

4. Organized a workshop on Active/Passive Imaging: Millimeter-Wave and Beyond in 2011 IMS and RFIC Symposiums. 11 top experst in this field were invited and presented their work in this one-day workshop.

 

5. Conducted a comprehensive study of on-chip antenna design at W-band in silicon. Designed and fabricated a slot dipole folded antenna, and got -4dBi of antenna gain at W-band. This was one of the highest antenna gain ever reported for an on-chip antenna design

 

6. Fabricated an integrated circuit that realizes a 2x2 focal plane array system, where each path (or element) is  comprised of direct conversion RX architecture and local frequency tripler in the local oscillator path. each RX itself is composed of a wideband low-noise amplifier (LNA), mixer, filters, baseband amplifiers, and an integrator. The LO distribution path is designed to be sophisticated so that it can generate 95 GHz signal and rout this signal to four corners of the chip. The LO network is comprised of a Ka-band phase-locked loop (PLL) generating 30 GHz signal, a symmetric H-tree coplanar waveguide (CPW) based LO distribution network that delivers the 30GHz signal to each on chip RX, and local frequency tripler connected to the end termination of H-free network. 

 

7. the responsivity of the RX was 270 MV/W (without considering antenna) and 48 MV/W (considering the antenna contribution). The core RX achieves highest responsivity of any other imaging RX reported before. The noise equivalent temperature difference (NETD) was reported to 3K accounting for on-chip antenna contribution.

 

8. Published two journals and two conferences on the subjects of this proposed activity during the 2nd year of this NSF grant.

9. Expolored new concept called, spatially overlapped super-pixels, which uses the inherenet spatial correlations between adjacent pixels to improve image resolution, and compensate for the lens abberations.  The main purpose of this new concept was to show the community the capability of designing an integrated sensor at millimeter wavelengths, with phase (time delay, for wide band systems) and amplitude control. This is limited to adjacent elements due to the high level of integration, and to provide an alternative to “isolated” pixels currently done at THz frequencies. 

10. We designed and implemented a W-band direct-detection-based receiver array which used this new concept of spatial-overlapping pixels for millimeter-wave imaging applications in an advanced 0.18 µm BiCMOS process. We showed through experiments that the novel use of spatial-overlapping pixels results in improved SNR at the pixel level, beam steering at the pixel level with the same pixel density as a traditional focal plane array and signal processing capabilities in the analog domain. The receiver chip achieved a peak measured coherent responsivity of 1,150 MV/W, a measured incoherent responsivity of 1,000 MV/W and a front-end 3 dB bandwidth from 87 to 108 GHz, while consuming 225 mW per receiver element. The measured NETD of the SiGe receiver chip is 0.45 K with a 20 ms integration time.
